The diameter of the bottle opening is <math alttext="1.03" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.03</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inches. To provide an acceptable fit, the cork diameter should be from <math alttext="0.99" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.99</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inch to <math alttext="1.03" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.03</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inches. The corks are purchased in bulk from a supplier, and the distribution of cork diameters is approximately normal with mean <math alttext="1.00" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.00</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inch and standard deviation <math alttext="0.05" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.05</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> inch.(a) If one cork is selected at random, what is the probability that the cork selected will provide an acceptable fit for the bottle? Show your work.A farm manager decides to purchase the corks from a new supplier. Seventy percent of corks produced by the new supplier have a diameter with an acceptable fit.

(b) The farm manager is investigating how many corks in a box of <math alttext="20" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> randomly selected corks will provide an acceptable fit. Consider the probability that at least <math alttext="19" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of the corks will provide an acceptable fit for the bottle.
(i) Define the random variable of interest and state how the random variable is distributed.

(ii) What is the probability that at least <math alttext="19" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>19</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> of the corks will provide an acceptable fit for the bottle? Show your work.

(c) Suppose corks are inspected one at a time until an acceptable fit is found. Let the random variable <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> represent the number of corks inspected. What is the probability that <math alttext="W" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>W</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is less than or equal to <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Show your work.
